messages: 2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:14): i am trying to mount my linux partition on solaris ext2fs filesystem and my partitions are complaining that there is no such
bcb81056a7a1b37648e04dc1ddd7afaf (12:16): pizdec: Solaris can not read ext2 partitions
bcb81056a7a1b37648e04dc1ddd7afaf (12:16): at least, it doesn't ship w/an ext2 driver
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:16): i have researched and got a promise for at least sol8
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:17): the problem is not with the driver that i have installed
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:17): it is with partition naming scheme and drive namings, i spent all sat on figuring out what my 750Gb disk will be
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:20): Partition   Status    Type          Start   End   Length    %
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:20): 4. Change between Solaris and Solaris2 Partition IDs
e55e49dbdc0b3b324ddec7711f265523 (12:21): please don't flood, use pastebin
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:21): Partition   Status    Type          Start   End   Length    %
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:23): i just don't see which partition that would be, and neither /dev/rdsk/c5d0p0 not /dev/rdsk/c5d0s0 nor other choices do anygood
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:23): so i wonder if anyone had similar problem or have deeper understanding of how solaris deals with partitions
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (12:24): What does "neither.... nor ... do any good" mean?
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (12:26): Are you *trying* to be obtuse?
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:26): mount: /dev/dsk/c5d0s0 is not a Linux filesystem.
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:26): mount: /dev/dsk/c5d0p0 is not a Linux filesystem.
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:27): as i understand s0 is Solaris FDISK partition
bcb81056a7a1b37648e04dc1ddd7afaf (12:27): pizdec: just a guess, but the old ext2 mounter probably can't deal with the new features introduced in recent ext[23] filesystems
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:27): so p0 is what i shall be looking for , but it is unrecognised by solaris as valid
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (12:27): s0 is *part* of the solaris fdisk partition.
bcb81056a7a1b37648e04dc1ddd7afaf (12:27): you might start by compiling the e2fsutils, and making sure that *they* can read the files on the partition
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:28): i have another one to try it that i know is linux from suse

bcb81056a7a1b37648e04dc1ddd7afaf (12:28): boyd: I'm next to positive actually... ext2 has a "features" bitmap which indicates that the on-disk FS uses features not present in the original design.  if an ext[23] mounter sees feature bits it doesn't understand, it should fail to mount the partition
bcb81056a7a1b37648e04dc1ddd7afaf (12:29): and there's another one (forget which) are recent, non-backwards-compatible e2fs features
bcb81056a7a1b37648e04dc1ddd7afaf (12:29): e2fsutils' "tune2fs" can disable some of those feature flags, might be worth a try
2e72cb7cc9514158ebeaf30934952078 (12:31): it was surely mkext3fs under suse 9.1
